Inbox Hero: How I Write Hypnotizing Emails That Convert Like Crazy

If someone was able to travel back in time and tell me 10 years ago that email would still be fundamental to how we communicate today, I probably would have dropped everything I was doing and started working on inventing a holographic communicator HoloLens.

Lame jokes aside.. email has helped me close more deals and has generated more revenue for my businesses than any other source (by a long shot) and I don’t see that changing any time soon.

Many of us send dozens of emails a day without giving much thought to the overall effectiveness or how we can optimize what we send to achieve even better results.

When something works, we quickly move on without thinking about how to take that small win and use it to create much more consistent wins.

The marketer in me is never satisfied when something just works.  I need to understand exactly why it’s working – because you can optimize and improve almost anything.

For example: Let’s say you have a consulting business and cold email potential clients. You’ve found that on average you land a meeting with 1 in 5 prospects you email and close 50% of those that you meet with.

This is actually great position to be in because often with a few simple changes to your initial funnel, it’s completely possible to take that 1 in 5 to 2 in 5 or even 3 in 5.  If your conversion rate for meetings remained the same you would effectively double or triple your overall conversion rate without changing your core business.

I’ve seen this work over and over and over again, with my own business and others, with newsletters AND with personal emails.

The key is making optimization a habit rather than an afterthought.

Cue the old school metaphor…

Optimization is like tuning a radio dial until you find the perfect frequency with the least amount of static or resistance.  If you’re sending out emails that people don’t reply to an email OR reply and are not interested, I like to think of that as static meaning that we need to adjust our frequency a bit.

Our goal is to move the dial until we find a frequency where hear the music loud and clear, and we hear something like this:

Over the years I’ve developed a few simple rules I follow when writing emails to investors, potential clients and customers that ensure the best possible chance of a preferred outcome.

In some cases this may simply be a phone call or meeting, but it’s also helped me land huge deals and consulting gigs.

Also, just to be clear – I’ve found many of the strategies in this post will work with personal one off emails OR with a newsletter, so there should be something for everyone here.

Rule 1. Formality is your enemy

We all battle awkward formality syndrome in our writing.

When emailing someone for business or who we view to be important, we are conditioned to go into this mode of over formality / creepyness and start using horrible canned phrases like “Hope all is well” and “I wanted to reach out”.

Formalities and canned phrases lead to lower conversion rates. Here’s why:

  1. You probably aren’t saying what you think you’re saying.

    Most people use canned phrases in an email when trying to be polite but it’s actually a blatant indication that either you don’t give a shit, or are contacting someone for personal gain.

    A great example of a terrible canned phrase that should be totally eliminated is one that I’ve been guilty of overusing in the past: “Hope all is well.”

    This is basically like saying.. “I really don’t care how things are and don’t want to give you an opportunity to respond.”

  2. Successful people are busy and don’t have time for formalities.

    This may or may not actually be true BUT it’s you shouldn’t have time to write an email with a ton of formalities.

    If you’re trying to get a phone call or meeting less is more.  The less you say in the email the less reason you give for someone to say no so it’s better to be short, to the point and look like you’re running a billion dollar empire. Your time should be worth it’s weight in gold.

  3. Human or Robot?

    Most of the emails we receive are automated and go out to tens of thousands or even millions of people (recent studies have indicated that automated emails and spam account for 99%+ of the total received).

    The problem here isn’t the amount of automation but that most of these emails are trying to sell us something and use language that is often overly polite and disingenuous.

There is really one very important take away from all three points above and it’s actually incredibly simple yet easily overlooked…

Embrace your humanity.  Your realness.  It’s the best sales tool that you have.

Speaking or writing to someone like a real human being rather than an object for profit is key.  There are so many areas in business that the human factor gets lost in translation but by focusing on this we can dramatically improve our conversion rates.

So using our example above, instead of saying “Hope all is well.” we should be saying.. “How have things been??” or “John – How is everything?”.

Language should be imperfect and human. Once I embraced the art of writing like I speak rather than trying to manufacture politeness the effectiveness of my emails increased dramatically.

Rule 2. Urgency is Key

Most people are constantly at war with procrastination. Email breeds procrastination simply because it requires more effort to respond to than a text message. So we need to do everything in our power to help them win the current battle, and luckily we have a secret weapon.

Urgency.

I’ve found that creating a sense of urgency can dramatically increase your conversion rate and the rate at which you are able to make things happen.

Doing this in almost any context is actually really simple. Here are a few examples that you can swap in and out of almost any email:

  • “Can you discuss on the phone now?”
  • “Can you do this now?”
  • “How can we get this done today?”

It really is as simple as that.

While you could state an actual deadline for something, I’ve found that it’s just as effective to imply a deadline using language like “now”.

Once you start intentionally using urgency in your emails you will be absolutely amazed at how much of your time was probably wasted in the past due to procrastination.

Rule 3. Subject Lines are a Distraction

Now that we’ve received the antidote for our awkward formality syndrome we can focus on writing an effective email subject line.

There are hundreds of existing blog posts out there with a ridiculously overwhelming number of strategies for writing email subjects with better open rates.

Today I want to share three of my super secret subject lines that I’ve spent tens of thousands of dollars and years of my life perfecting, fine tuning and optimizing…

Are you ready?

  1. “Hey”
  2. “No Subject”
  3. “Re:subject”

Probably not what you were expecting? I actually don’t put much effort into crafting my subject lines anymore and instead use simple words like “Hey” or no subject at all – interestingly my open rates have gone way up.

While you should actually give a shit when writing email copy, the “I don’t give a shit” approach with subject lines works really well for a few reasons.

People have a tendency to overcomplicated things.  The problem with trying to craft a perfect subject line is that you are introducing a whole new set of unknowns and variables into the equation.

Remember, 99%+ of the emails we receive are automated. Many of these are sent by huge companies with enormous marketing budgets, much of which is spent on optimization.

Since we really can’t compete with that – especially for sending one off emails, we need to work around it and we do it by again embracing imperfection and realness.  

Important note: This approach works incredibly well for single emails but you need to be careful when mailing a newsletter or list. That is a whole different beast and relevancy in your subject line can affect unsubscribes.  Sending someone a newsletter with “Hey” as the subject usually doesn’t end well. Instead, I recommend keeping the subject line short, relevant, to the point while still using imperfection and realness to your advantage.

My Bag of Bonus Tricks

  1. Response required:  I almost always include a question that requires a response the end of any email. Asking a question usually increases engagement and ensures that the recipient reads your full email.

  2. Avoid the spam pit:  This really warrants its own post but to keep things short and sweet…

    • Avoid punctuation in your subject line.
    •  Don’t link to 20 different things – one link per email max.
    • I also set up various test email accounts with Gmail, Yahoo, Outlook and will send myself a test to make sure that there is zero chance of getting stuck in spam. I’ve actually found Yahoo to be the most random / notorious.
  3. Working hard or hardly working? Sometimes I like to send emails at 2 or 3 am because entrepreneurs never sleep right?  Wrong – you can write your email during normal business hours and schedule them to stand out. I also use Buffer to schedule social media posts.
  4. “From” should not be your business name: I’ve found that email addresses that use the name of a business vs the name of a person or employee have a much lower open rate.  Always verify that your “From” field uses your name and not the name of your business. So for example the Startup Workout newsletter is always from me personally, not Startup Workout.

  5. Track your progress: I highly recommend using a CRM and setting up a sales pipeline.  I prefer Streak which is built right into Gmail.

    For a sales pipeline I will generally set up something like the following:

    1. Initial Email
    2. Second Email
    3. Third Email
    4. Meeting Scheduled
    5. No Response
    6. Not Interested
  6. If you don’t get a response: Don’t send a second or third email right away.  Wait a few days or a week and resend the same email. This is actually a tip I picked up from this great post on Medium, and it works like magic.
